pubinfo.publish: National Atlas of the United States

citeinfo.origin: United States. Bureau of the Census. Geography Division
citeinfo.title: National Atlas of the United States

descript.abstract: This dataset represents the locations and attributes of significant, historic earthquakes that caused deaths, property damage, and geological effects, or were otherwise experienced by populations in the United States, Puerto Rico, and U.S. Virgin Islands. Included are earthquakes located in the United States as well as some that occurred in adjacent portions of Canada and Mexico. The main sources for the data are Seismicity of the United States, 1568-1989 and the Preliminary Determination of Epicenters for 1990 to August 2009. This is a replacement for the January 2005 map layer.
descript.purpose: This dataset is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.
descript.supplinf: Provided with the downloadable files is a text file, quksigx_references.txt, which contains the reference information for earthquake magnitudes listed in the data.

idinfo.datacred: The following U.S. Geological Survey scientists contributed to this map layer: A. Tarr, M. Hopper, J. Dewey, M. McKeever, and N. Trevor.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

attracc.attraccr: Attribute information remains the same as given by the author of the data. However, when information is missing or ambiguous, the GIS Information Systems Center at Tufts University researches other metadata sources for explanations. If sufficient information is unavailable, "unknown attribute" is given as the definition. If the attribute has been created through a geoprocessing function, "geoprocessed identifier" is given. If the attribute is known, but the values are not, "unknown" is given for values. Features' units of measurement are determined if not already given.

dataqual.logic: No formal tests for logical consistency were performed on this map layer, principally because the map layer contains attribute values that were arrived at by either or both quantitative (i.e. instrumental) and qualitative (i.e. historical) methods. Earthquakes that occurred prior to the introduction of seismological instrumentation are known only from written records, such as newspapers, books and journals, and diaries, which often may provide contradictory information that has to be carefully examined and weighed. As seismographs became more common in the early 1960's, the origin time and location were both more precisely and accurately determined but the compilation and evaluation of intensity reports was, and still is, a process that involves considerable subjectivity. As a result, all attributes associated with a given earthquake should be considered provisional and subject to further revision based on acquisition of new information and use of new analytical methods.
dataqual.complete: This map layer contains information on significant, historical earthquakes that caused deaths, property damage, geological effects, or that were experienced by populations in the epicentral area, for the United States, Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands. These data are limited to the best estimates of earthquake locations and to attributes such as magnitude and maximum intensity.

horizpa.horizpar: 100 meter is the nominal precision of the reported instrumentally located coordinate values but accuracy is considerably less. Accuracy depends upon numerous factors including imprecision of the velocity model of the earth, uneven distribution of seismic stations, and imprecisions in the computational algorithm. Following initial proofreading of the input data file, a preliminary map of the locations of the earthquakes was produced which was examined for gross errors in spatial location.

vertacc.vertaccr: Although depths are reported to the nearest 1 kilometer, the accuracy is considerably less owing to uncertainties in the velocity model of the Earth, uneven distribution of seismic stations, and imprecisions in the computational algorithm.

srcinfo.srccontr: Principal source of earthquake locations and attributes.
Supplemental source of earthquake locations and attributes.

citeinfo.title: Earthquake History of the United States

srcinfo.srccontr: Supplemental source of earthquake locations and attributes.

procstep.procdesc: Data for the years 1568 to 1989, from Seismicity of the United States, were combined with Preliminary Determination of Epicenters data for 1990 to 2009. EHUS1982 and MIDAS-IPGH were used to compile information for additional locations or for years not covered by the other sources. The resulting text file was loaded into ArcView and converted to a shapefile. Three records for Puerto Rico were dropped because they did not include values for longitude and latitude.

In order to meet Tufts University's metadata standards: >Defined projection (NAD 1983) >Imported metadata from provided quksigx020.txt (arcgis 9.3) >Changed formatting of IsO 19115 Topic Category keywords to match proper formatting >Changed access contraints from "None" to "Unrestricted Access Online" >Changed citation title from "quksigx020" to "Significant Historic Earthquakes USA 2009" >Changed name of file from "quksigx020" to "USAearthquakes09" >Substituted "Geological Survey (U.S.)" for "U. S. Geological Survey" as the originator >Added Larger Work Citation >Added theme keyword "point" to added theme keyword thesaurus "FGDC" >Added LCSH theme keywords >Added GNIS and GNS place keywords >Replaced Tufts as the distributor >Exported metadata

spdoinfo.indspref: U.S. Department of Commerce, 1987, Codes for the Identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the Outlying Areas of The United States, and Associated Areas (Federal Information Processing Standard 5-2): Washington, DC, National Institute of Standards and Technology.

enttyp.enttypd: Earthquakes within or near to the United States that caused deaths, property damage, or geological effects, or that were experienced by populations in the epicentral area. These events occurred between 1568 and August 2009.
enttyp.enttypds: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The body wave magnitude of the earthquake as reported by the U.S. Geological Survey. A body wave is a seismic wave that travels through the Earth's inner layers.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The body wave magnitude is unknown.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The surface wave magnitude of the earthquake as reported by the U.S. Geological Survey. A surface wave is a seismic wave that travels along the Earth's surface.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The surface wave magnitude is unknown.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The magnitude of the earthquake as reported by the source identified in Ref1. The type of magnitude is described by the attribute Type1.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: No additional magnitude measurement is available.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The type of magnitude recorded in the attribute Other_mag1, as defined by the source identified in Ref1.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is an estimated body wave magnitude. It is commonly computed from the felt area for earthquakes which occurred before seismic instruments were in general use.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is based on the duration or coda length of the earthquake vibration.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the local magnitude, which is also known as the original "Richter" magnitude.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the moment magnitude. It is the measure of total energy released by an earthquake.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the local or regional magnitude. It is the body wave magnitude using the Lg wave.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the surface wave magnitude. A surface wave is a seismic wave that travels along the Earth's surface.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the moment magnitude.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The magnitude type for the magnitude given in Other_mag1 is unknown.

edom.edomvd: The magnitude given in Other_mag1 is the body wave magnitude. A body wave is a seismic wave that travels through the Earth's inner layers.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The type of magnitude given in Other_mag1 is unknown. The value came from Coffman, Jerry L., and von Hake, Carl A., 1973, Earthquake History of the United States: U.S. Dept. of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Publication 41-1, Revised Edition (Through 1970).

attr.attrdef: Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI), where the integer value represents the Roman numeral designation of the MMI intensity.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey

edom.edomvd: The earthquake was felt but no Modified Mercalli Intensity was assigned.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: An earthquake felt only by a few persons at rest, especially on upper floors of buildings. Delicately suspended objects may swing.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake felt quite noticeably by persons indoors, especially on upper floors of buildings. Many people do not recognize it as an earthquake. Standing motor cars may rock slightly. Vibration similar to the passing of a truck. Duration estimated in some cases.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake felt indoors by many, outdoors by few during the day. At night, some awakened. Dishes, windows, doors disturbed; walls make cracking sound. Sensation like heavy truck striking building. Standing motor cars rocked noticeably.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake felt by nearly everyone; many awakened. Some dishes, windows broken. Unstable objects overturned. Pendulum clocks may stop.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake felt by all; many frightened. Some heavy furniture moved; a few instances of fallen plaster. Damage slight.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake causing negligible damage in buildings of good design and construction; slight to moderate in well-built ordinary structures; considerable damage in poorly built or badly designed structures; some chimneys broken. Noticed by persons driving motor cars.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake causing slight damage in specially designed structures; considerable in ordinary substantial buildings with partial collapse. Damage great in poorly built structures. Fall of chimneys, factory stacks, columns, monuments, walls. Heavy furniture overturned.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake causing considerable damage in specially designed structures; well-designed frame structures thrown out of plumb. Damage great in substantial buildings, with partial collapse. Buildings shifted off foundations.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquaking causing destruction of some well-built wooden structures; most masonry and frame structures destroyed with foundations. Railroad rails bent.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake where few, if any (masonry) structures remain standing. Bridges destroyed. Railroad rails bent greatly.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

edom.edomvd: An earthquake where damage is total. Lines of sight and level distorted. Objects thrown into the air.
edom.edomvds: <http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/epic/mm_scale.html>

attr.attrdef: The area, in square kilometers, in which the earthquake was felt.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: The area in which the earthquake was felt is unknown.
edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The primary source of the earthquake information.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvd: Coffman, J.L., von Hake, C.A., and Stover, C.W., 1982, Earthquake History of the United States: U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and U.S. Geological Survey, Publication No. 41-1, revised edition, [through 1980], 258p.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey

edom.edomvd: Tanner, J.G. and Shepherd, J.B., 1997, Project catalogue and seismic hazard maps, Seismic hazard in Latin America and the Caribbean: Panamerican Institute of Geography and History, v. 1, 143 p.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey

edom.edomvd: Preliminary Determination of Epicenters, a list of earthquakes located by the National Earthquake Information Center of the U.S. Geological Survey and its predecessors in the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey, the National Oceanic Survey, and the Environmental Research Laboratories of the Department of Commerce. The PDE is comprised of final hypocenter and magnitude computations by the USGS NEIC published in monthly lists several months after the events.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey

edom.edomvd: Stover, Carl W., and Coffman, Jerry L., 1993a, Seismicity of the United States, 1568-1989 (Revised): U.S. Geological Survey Professional Paper 1527, 418 p.
edom.edomvds: U.S. Geological Survey
